title: 112_hr436
content: The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" includes provisions such as the repeal of the medical device excise tax, disqualification of expenses for over-the-counter drugs, taxable distributions of unused balances under health flexible spending arrangements, and recapture of overpayments from federally-subsidized health insurance. The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" repeals the medical device excise tax and disqualifies expenses for over-the-counter drugs under certain accounts and arrangements. The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" makes amendments to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including HSAs, Archer MSAs, and Health Flexible Spending Arrangements. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2012. Additionally, the Act addresses taxable distributions of unused balances under Health Flexible Spending Arrangements. The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" amends the Internal Revenue Code to address taxable distributions of unused balances under Health Flexible Spending Arrangements. It ensures that such arrangements providing for qualified distributions are still treated as cafeteria plans or health flexible spending arrangements. The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" amends the Internal Revenue Code to define a "qualified distribution" as a distribution to an individual under a specific arrangement after the last date for reimbursement requests for the plan year, not exceeding $500 or the excess of salary reduction contributions over reimbursements. The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" defines a "qualified distribution" as a reimbursement for medical expenses under a specific arrangement. Qualified distributions are taxable as wages when distributed and do not include qualified reservist distributions. The "Health Care Cost Reduction Act of 2012" defines a "qualified distribution" as a reimbursement for medical expenses under a specific arrangement. The act also includes a conforming amendment to section 409A(d) of the Code, adding a health flexible spending arrangement under section 125. These amendments apply to plan years starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 5. RECAPTURE OF OVERPAYMENTS RESULTING FROM CERTAIN FEDERALLY-SUBSIDIZED HEALTH INSURANCE. Amends section 36B(f) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to address excess advance payments. Effective for taxable years ending after December 31, 2013.
